description: Attested since the 1300s, as Middle English bom (found in John Trevisa's 1387 Translation of the 'Polychronicon' of Ranulph Higden, "his bom is oute"), of uncertain origin. Sometimes suggested to be a shortening of botme, botom, bottum (“bottom”), but this is contradicted by the fact that bottom is not attested in reference to the buttocks until the late 1700s. Suggested by some old and modern references to be onomatopoeic. Compare also Old Irish, Scottish Gaelic bun (“base, bottom”).

entries.meaning: (informal or childish, chiefly Commonwealth) The buttocks.
examples: Synonyms: see Thesaurus:buttocks
Okay, everyone sit on your bum and try and touch your toes.

entries.meaning: (informal or childish, chiefly Commonwealth) The anus.
examples: Synonyms: see Thesaurus:anus

verbs.description: bum (third-person singular simple present bums, present participle bumming, simple past and past participle bummed)

entries.meaning: (UK, transitive, colloquial) To sodomize; to engage in anal sex.

description: 1864, back-formation from bummer, from German Bummler (“loafer”), from bummeln (“to loaf”).

entries.meaning: (slang) Of poor quality or highly undesirable.
examples: bum note
a bum deal

entries.meaning: (slang) Injured and without the possibility of full repair, defective.
examples: Synonym: (UK) duff
I can't play football anymore on account of my bum knee.
He had a bum trip on that mescaline.

entries.meaning: (US, Canada, UK, Ireland, Australia, New Zealand, colloquial, derogatory) A homeless person, usually a man.
examples: Synonyms: tramp, vagrant, wanderer, vagabond; see also Thesaurus:vagabond

entries.meaning: (US, Canada, UK, Ireland, Australia, New Zealand, colloquial, derogatory) A lazy, incompetent, or annoying person, usually a man.
examples: Synonyms: loafer, bumpkin, footler; see also Thesaurus:idler
Fred is becoming a bum - he's not even bothering to work more than once a month.
That mechanic's a bum - he couldn't fix a yo-yo.
That guy keeps interrupting the concert. Throw the bum out!

entries.meaning: (US, Canada, UK, Ireland, Australia, New Zealand, colloquial, sports) A player or racer who often performs poorly.
examples: Trade him to another team, he's a bum!
Synonyms: binge, bender

verbs.description: bum (third-person singular simple present bums, present participle bumming, simple past and past participle bummed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, colloquial)  To ask someone to give one (something) for free; to beg for something.
examples: Synonyms: (British) cadge; see also Thesaurus:scrounge
Can I bum a cigarette off you?

entries.meaning: (intransitive, colloquial) To stay idle and unproductive, like a hobo or vagabond.
examples: Synonym: loiter
I think I'll just bum around downtown for awhile until dinner.

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang, Britain) To wet the end of a marijuana cigarette (spliff).

verbs.description: bum (third-person singular simple present bums, present participle bumming, simple past and past participle bummed)
bum (third-person singular simple present bums, present participle bumming, simple past and past participle bummed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To make a murmuring or humming sound.

examples: About her Chariot, and behind, / Were Sergeants, Bums of every kind, / Tip-staffs, and all those Officers, / That squeeze a Living out of Tears.
